title: 111_hr6019
content: The "Accountability and Transparency in Ethics Act of 2010" is also known as the Lobbying Ban for Members and Employees of Congress and Executive Branch Officials. The "Accountability and Transparency in Ethics Act of 2010" includes amendments to Section 207 of title 18, United States Code, increasing the time period from one year to two years in various subsections. The "Accountability and Transparency in Ethics Act of 2010" amends Section 207 of title 18, United States Code, increasing the time period from one year to two years in various subsections. The amendments apply to individuals leaving office or employment more than 120 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. PROHIBITING PAYMENT OF CAMPAIGN FUNDS TO IMMEDIATE FAMILY MEMBERS OF CANDIDATES. Prohibition on payments to spouses and immediate family members for services provided to candidate committees or leadership PACs, except for nominal reimbursements for supplies and equipment used. The text prohibits payments to spouses and immediate family members for services to candidate committees or leadership PACs, except for nominal reimbursements under $500 per year. Definitions for 'immediate family member' and 'leadership PAC' are provided. A conforming amendment is made to section 313(a)(1) of the Act. The amendments made by this section shall apply with respect to payments made on or after the date of the enactment of this Act, subject to subsection (d). ETHICS TRAINING FOR LOBBYISTS. The Committee on Standards of Official Conduct provides an 8-hour ethics training course for lobbyists registered under the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995. The training covers the code of conduct, disclosure requirements, gift acceptance rules, and financial disclosure requirements for Members, officers, and employees of the House of Representatives. Failure to complete the training course during each Congress will result in penalties under the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995. Failure to comply with the ethics training course for lobbyists under the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 will result in penalties under the Act. The Congress emphasizes that any changes to the Office of Congressional Ethics should enhance its powers to improve accountability and transparency. Additionally, the Office of Congressional Ethics is granted subpoena power. The Office of Congressional Ethics, established by House Resolution 895 (110th Congress), has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses and documents necessary for its duties. Subpoenas can be issued by the chairman and cochairman or by a vote of 4 members of the board. Subpoenas can be served by the chairman or a designated member. The chairman or a designated member may administer oaths to witnesses as needed.
